awd_titl_txt: Electrophysiological measures of neuroplasticity with reading intervention
awd_abstract_narration:
Reading proficiency is fundamental to school and subsequent career success, yet national statistics show that only about one-third of US fourth graders are proficient readers. Very little is known about how learning to read is reflected in brain changes. The goal of this project is to investigate how a reading intervention results in changes in brain activity associated with recognizing words, recognizing sound-letter correspondences, and memory for auditory information.  This will provide important insights into how reading skills are acquired and what types of interventions might be most effective for those who are having difficulty learning to read. 

The project uses a pre-post design to investigate plasticity of neural systems involved in lexical processing, phonological processing, and working memory components of reading.  The study uses both behavioral and event-related potential (ERP) measures to investigate how an established reading intervention changes specific neural systems in 8- and 9-year-old children who are struggling readers. Brain waves will be recorded before and after the intervention to explore the plasticity of (1) the lexical processing system, addressing whether the intervention sharpens the neural response to words (e.g., bed) as compared to non-words (e.g., dbe); (2) the phonological processing system, addressing whether the intervention changes the neural response to rhyming information; and (3) the working memory system, addressing whether the intervention alters the timing or amount of resources used to remember sounds. Scores on a battery of standardized tests of reading and reading-related skills will document behavioral changes that occur with intervention. Overall, this project will advance understanding of the specific neural changes resulting from the intervention and improved reading abilities.  A key impact of this project is the opportunity to increase the chance of educational success for struggling readers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
We used both behavioral and neural (event-related potential, or ERP) measures to track change over time, before and after provision of a one-on-one, phonics-based intervention to third- and fourth-grade struggling readers with poor decoding skills. To our knowledge, this is the first study to purposefully pair multiple behavioral and ERP measures to track change over the period of a phonics intervention in English. We found changes in word, sound, and memory processing. Without a control group, it is not possible to attribute these changes to the intervention. In terms of word processing, word and nonword reading accuracy and fluency scores on standardized behavioral tests improved over time, and there was greater tuning to words (as compared to unpronounceable letter strings) over time as indexed by the N170 component of the ERP waveform. In terms of sound processing, scores on a standardized test of sound awareness improved over time, and a nonsignificant ERP rhyming effect at pre-testing trended toward significance at post-testing. In terms of memory, scores on a standardized digit span test decreased over time, and there was ERP evidence of faster memory updating in terms of the latency of the P300 component in an auditory oddball paradigm. Behaviorally, this is a heartening pattern of improvement in reading and reading-related skills over time; electrophysiologically, this is evidence regarding the plasticity of neural systems involved in processing words and speech sounds, as well as auditory memory, in upper elementary students.

To explore how these neural and behavioral changes over developmental time were related, we ran correlation analyses. None of the correlations between the ostensibly matched behavioral and neural measures of change were significant; that is, change in single word and nonword reading scores was not correlated with change in the N170 effect, change in sound awareness scores was not correlated with change in the ERP rhyming effect, and change in digit span was not correlated with change in the P300 effect over the same time period in the same children. Although our small sample size (N = 17) was adequate to detect change over time (see above), it may not have been sufficient to detect correlations. Overall, though, the pattern of findings suggests that standardized behavioral tests and ERPs can index different aspects of neurocognitive processing - and thus that each can contribute complementary, nonduplicative information concerning change in struggling readers. In turn, this provides support for the contention that combining these different types of measures spanning across levels of analysis - using multiple neural and behavioral measures - might provide greater explanatory power in unpacking and understanding the course and complexity of reading development, and thus in helping struggling readers. 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Donna J Coch
